definition:
In this definition, all rings are assumed to be rings with identity and
all ring homomorphisms are assumed to be unital.

Let $R$ be a ring. An *algebra* over $R$ is a ring $A$ together with a
ring homomorphism $f\colon R \to Z(A)$, where $Z(A)$ denotes the center
of $A$. A *subalgebra* of $A$ is a subset of $A$ which is an algebra.

Equivalently, an algebra over a ring $R$ is an $R$–module $A$ which is a
ring and satisfies the property
$$r\cdot(x*y) = (r\cdot x)*y = x*(r\cdot y)$$ for all $r \in R$ and all
$x,y \in A$. Here $\cdot$ denotes $R$-module multiplication and $*$
denotes ring multiplication in $A$. One passes between the two
definitions as follows: given any ring homomorphism
$f\colon R \longrightarrow Z(A)$, the scalar multiplication rule
$$r \cdot b := f(r)*b$$ makes $A$ into an $R$-module in the sense of the
second definition. Conversely, if $A$ satisfies the requirements of the
second definition, then the function $f\colon R \to A$ defined by
$f(r) := r \cdot 1$ is a ring homomorphism from $R$ into $Z(A)$.
